Highlights ► Proposed one-sided VCG (Vickrey–Clarke–Groves) combinatorial auctions for a complex transportation marketplace with multiple lanes, realizing maximal social welfare. ► Designed three truthful multi-unit trade reduction (MTR) mechanisms for the bilateral exchange transportation marketplace where all the lanes are partitioned into distinct markets. ► Developed a randomized auction mechanism to capture the trade-off between the O-VCG and MTR auction classes. Abstract This paper is among the first contributions that incorporate bilateral bidding into auction mechanism design for multi-unit transportation procurement in logistics e-marketplaces. Proposed mechanisms ensure incentive compatibility, individual rationality, budget balance and asymptotical efficiency. We first consider one-sided VCG (Vickrey–Clarke–Groves) combinatorial auctions for a complex transportation marketplace with multiple lanes, realizing the maximal social welfare. We then design three alternative multi-unit trade reduction (MTR) mechanisms for the bilateral exchange transportation marketplace where all the lanes are partitioned into distinct markets. Compared to the base MTR mechanism, more buyers/shippers win the “tickets” for competing in the final trade in the MTR-BA (buyer augment) mechanism; likewise, more sellers/carriers win these tickets in the MTR-SA (seller augment) mechanism. Under the buyer and seller augment mechanisms, both shippers’ and carriers’ expected utilities are higher than those in the base MTR mechanism. Numerical study further shows that MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms lead to higher expected utilities for shippers and carriers respectively than social welfare maximization. However, the base MTR mechanism provides a higher payoff to the market broker than MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms. Finally, we propose a randomized mechanism that integrates one-sided VCG mechanisms and MTR mechanisms. As a result, this randomized mechanism is practical in both the one-sided and bilateral exchange transportation marketplaces, even with the less-than-truckload constraint. Keywords Mechanism design Auctions Transportation service procurement Incentive compatibility 1 Introduction Transportation service procurement (TSP) is the problem of determining transportation and exchange relationships across a transportation market, which consists of shippers, carriers and a third-party exchange service provider. The shippers (typically large manufacturers or retailers) provide logistics jobs to get their components or goods transported between their business partners. The transportation service of a carrier (e.g., a trucking company) can be bought at the prevailing price in the market, or alternatively through a procurement contract for a specified time horizon with negotiated rates and service level agreements. This kind of contract is commonly sought through a competitive request for proposal (RFP). This contract ensures the transportation service provisions between specific origin–destination pairs (called lanes) (Song and Regan, 2005; Lee et al., 2007). The third-party exchange service provider is actually a market broker between shippers and carriers. The third-party exchange service is delivered through a technology platform (e.g., spot market, e-marketplace) to facilitate the trading between shippers and carriers. This service platform allows shippers and carriers to share their needs and capacities. Usually the business relationships in a transportation market are established through long-term contracts (Sheffi, 2004). However, there has been an increasing need to automate this TSP process as business relationships become ever more dynamic and flexible. For example, when the prevailing price of transportation service drops significantly (e.g., sudden fuel price drops, entrance of new carriers), a shipper may have to breach the contract with long-time carriers by paying a certain penalty cost to purchase these services at the prevailing price or renegotiate a new contract. Moreover, empty movements account for a large percentage of the 80 billion dollars wasted in transportation in the US each year – which is more than 10% of revenue (Nair, 2005). These massive spare capacities signify a great potential for cost reduction. Recently, Internet commerce has successfully permeated into freight transportation marketplaces. Some examples of these Internet-based transactions can be found in http://www.leanlogistics.com, http://www.besttransport.com, http://www.nte.com or its sister company http://www.audacious1.com. With the rise of logistics e-marketplaces and smart logistics technologies such as RFID (radio frequency identification devices) and cloud computing, it would be possible to turn those empty movements into a gain for individual carriers and shippers, and further an increase in economy and efficiency for transportation market. Unfortunately, few game theoretical models known so far are able to make a realistic representation of these new transportation trading markets. The market broker makes decisions to maximize profits on the basis of the system efficiency. In addition, the information sharing among the entire transportation market is not complete. These characteristics make it difficult to determine the optimal transportation and exchange relationships by using the traditional RFP approach. As the TSP problem is complicated, new analytical methods are required for better understanding of each agent’s behavior and rules of capacity allocation and payment transfer. An increasing number of studies of auctions for TSP are now available in the transportation research literature (e.g., Ledyard et al., 2002; Song and Regan, 2003, 2005; Sheffi, 2004; Lee et al., 2007; Figliozzi et al., 2007; Ağrali et al., 2008; Day and Raghavan, 2009; Chang, 2009; Mes et al., 2010; Robu et al., 2011). These papers demonstrate the enormous potential that online auctions would lead to the transportation market efficiency. Auction mechanisms have played significant roles in the TSP research. Auction is “a market institution with an explicit set of rules determining resource allocation and prices on the basis of bids from the market participants” (McAfee and McMillan, 1987). As in the standard auction literature, there are four principles as the primary goals of auction mechanism design: (1) allocative efficiency (AE) – the allocation solution maximizes the sum of agents’ values; (2) incentive compatibility (IC) – truthful bidding reaches a Bayesian–Nash equilibrium; (3) (ex-post) individual rationality (IR) – all agents have non-negative utility from participation; and (4) (ex-post weak) budget balance (BB) – the trade does not run at a deficit (Krishna, 2002). Unfortunately, it is well known that no bilateral exchange can be simultaneously AE, BB (even in the ex-ante case), and IR (Myerson and Satterthwaite, 1983). It is clear that two types of objects could be exchanged in transportation marketplaces: (1) lanes/demands of shippers, which can be traded by reverse auctions; and (2) capacities of carriers, which can be traded by forward auctions. Alternatively, double auctions could be used in the case of multiple shippers and carriers. However, to date, there has been relatively little attention devoted to forward auctions under which shippers are treated as bidders, or double auctions in bilateral exchange transportation marketplaces. Furthermore, most of the reverse (carrier-as-bidder) auctions in the extant transportation literature are not IC. Apparently no exchange mechanism can ensure AE if IC is sacrificed. Also, AE in these reverse auctions means one-sided value maximization (e.g., the minimization of total transportation cost or empty movement cost) which is not equivalent to social welfare maximization, unless in the case of one shipper and multiple carriers. Garrido (2007) develops a “double auction” scheme for the shippers with elastic demand and economic order quantity policy, to contract each shipment to a single carrier. However, the term “double auction” in Garrido (2007) is used merely to describe the transportation exchange environment under which both shippers and carriers could be bidders and auctioneers but without bilateral bidding, which is not the case in the bilateral trading literature (Myerson and Satterthwaite, 1983). In contrast, the well-known VCG (Vickrey–Clarke–Groves) auction (Vickrey, 1961; Clarke, 1971; Groves, 1973) is IC, IR and AE, but fails BB in the bilateral trading environments. In this paper, we focus on freight trucking, which is important not only in China but also in worldwide logistics businesses. For example, trucking represents the largest percentage (approximately 29%) of the US for-hire transportation services GDP in 2010 (NTS, 2011, p. 197, Table 3.1). We exploit the fact that, despite the impossibility theorem (Myerson and Satterthwaite, 1983), it is possible to realize: (i) all of the four principles (AE, IC, IR, and BB) in one-sided auctions; and (ii) IC with any two of the three principles (AE, IR, and BB) in double auctions. To address (i), we introduce one-sided VCG combinatorial auctions for a complex transportation marketplace with multiple lanes. These VCG auctions can realize AE, IC, IR and BB, with or without the constraint of less-than-truckload. To address (ii), we use the ideas from the classic single-unit trade reduction mechanism (McAfee, 1992) to design multi-unit trade reduction auctions for the bilateral exchange transportation marketplace where all the lanes are partitioned into distinct markets. The proposed multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms ensure IC, IR, and BB. Also our multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms are asymptotically efficient; that is, the market inefficiency under the multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms compared to the maximal social welfare converges to zero as the number of participants approaches infinity. The higher the market efficiency is, the more likely an auction mechanism is to yield higher revenues for the third-party marketplace in the long run (Wise and Morrison, 2000). To link one-sided VCG mechanisms and multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms, we further propose a randomized mechanism that is IC, IR, BB and asymptotically efficient. In addition, we demonstrate that this randomized mechanism is practical in both the one-sided and bilateral exchange transportation marketplaces, even with the less-than-truckload constraint. This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review the literature related to auction-based TSP and trade reduction mechanism. We describe our basic models in Section 3. In Section 4, we formulate VCG combinatorial auctions for TSP in one-sided settings. In Section 5, we introduce multi-unit trade reduction auctions for TSP in two-sided settings and analyze the proposed models analytically and numerically, and then propose a randomized mechanism that integrates one-sided VCG mechanisms and multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms. Our conclusions and some key directions for further research are given in Section 6. 2 Literature review Auction-based TSP has received a great deal of attention in transportation research. There are two broad research themes in the literature. The first stream of research investigates the modeling and performance of sequential auction marketplaces in which demands of shippers arrive randomly over time and each arrived demand is successfully auctioned before another one comes in Figliozzi et al. (2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007), Mes et al. (2007, 2009, 2010), and Ağrali et al. (2008). These studies on sequential auctions are usually set in dynamic and stochastic environments. Along with this theme, Figliozzi et al. (2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007) conduct some important studies. Figliozzi et al. (2003) present a framework for the carriers’ strategies in an auction-based marketplace for dynamic full truckload vehicle routing problems with time windows, and explore the complexities of sequential auction bidding. Figliozzi et al. (2004) study the competitiveness of different vehicle routing strategies on the travel costs under various demand conditions. Figliozzi et al. (2005) evaluate the impact of auction settings and bidding learning mechanisms on the transportation marketplace performance. Figliozzi et al. (2006) quantify the opportunity costs of sequential transportation auctions with time-sensitive pickup-and-delivery requests. In a similar setting, Mes et al. (2009, 2010) propose revenue maximizing strategies for shippers, and then present an opportunity based pricing and scheduling model. Unlike the definition in Figliozzi et al. (2006), the “opportunity costs” of sequential transportation auctions in Mes et al. (2010) are defined over multiple orders to be acquired within a specific time horizon and these functions are used to price a new order, but also to sequence the orders. Figliozzi et al. (2007) investigate carrier sequential pricing decisions for a type of vehicle routing problems in a dynamic and competitive environment. Mes et al. (2007) consider the real-time scheduling of full truckload transportation orders that arrive randomly with time windows. They minimize the total transportation costs and employ the reverse Vickrey auction (Vickrey, 1961) for each incoming order. Using the same auction mechanism, Ağrali et al. (2008) develop a Markovian queuing model to evaluate the transportation marketplace performance. The second theme focuses on combinatorial auctions which allow a single bid for a set of distinct lanes from a single or multiple shippers (Ledyard et al., 2002; Song and Regan, 2003; Caplice and Sheffi, 2003; Sheffi, 2004; Song and Regan, 2005; Lee et al., 2007; Day and Raghavan, 2009; Chang, 2009). Different from the research on the first theme, the combinatorial auctions for TSP are usually static. Combinatorial auctions are essentially simultaneous multi-unit auction paradigms. In the context of TSP, carriers have to maximize their capacity utilization and balance delivery requirements such as distinct destinations and arrival time windows. Combining distinct lanes into a single bid enables carriers to achieve the economics of scope (Caplice and Sheffi, 2003; Sheffi, 2004). Also, it is argued that allowing carriers to place single bids on packages of synergic lanes will lead to procurement cost reduction for shippers (Caplice and Sheffi, 2003). Ledyard et al. (2002) discuss a multi-round combinatorial auction used at Sears Inc. for contracting three year truckload carrier services and millions of dollars are saved compared to costs incurred using traditional procurement methods. Elmaghraby and Keskinocak (2004) describe the successful use of a combinatorial auction for TSP by Home Depot Inc., Wal-Mart Stores, Compaq Computer Co. and many others. For a review of the state of the art on the application of combinatorial auctions in the freight transportation, readers can refer to Sheffi (2004). Yet the design and use of combinatorial auctions for TSP is still faced with tough challenges. Caplice and Sheffi (2003) give a thorough review of important practical issues related to the execution of combinatorial auctions for truckload procurement. As pointed out by Parkes et al. (2001), winner determination is NP-hard for general combinatorial exchange problems and becomes more intractable as problem size increases. A detailed review of formulations and algorithms for the winner determination problems can be found at de Vries and Vohra (2003). In addition, carriers have to identify optimal bids for bundles of lanes and thus face the bidding optimization problem introduced by Song and Regan (2003). Given that the number of groups of lanes is rather large, bid valuation and construction problem for carriers is difficult and involves the computation of a number of NP-hard sub problems (Parkes, 2000; Song and Regan, 2005). Rothkopf et al. (1998) discuss the restricted structures of bids under different scenarios in combinatorial auctions so that bid generation can be tractable. Song and Regan (2005) use the 0–1 enumeration method of Balas to solve the bid construction problem with and without pre-existing commitments made by the carriers. In this method, the total empty movement effort is minimized, and carriers compute optimal truck routes for the packages of lanes. In the study of Lee et al. (2007), routes are constructed by optimally trading off repositioning costs of vehicles and the rewards associated with servicing lanes. This model comprises a simultaneous generation of vehicle routes and lane selection. Column generation and Lagrangian techniques are proposed for solving the resulting optimization problem. Recently, Day and Raghavan (2009) present a method for generating tractable bid sets by imposing certain restrictions known as matrix bidding. Chang (2009) develop a bidding model for facilitating the bid evaluation and generation process in one-shot combinatorial auctions. The proposed model in Chang (2009) integrates the carriers’ current fleet management plans with order information in transportation marketplaces, and then selects the desirable load packages. However, none of the above papers consider forward auctions under which shippers are treated as bidders or double auctions in bilateral exchange environments. Furthermore, most of the reverse auctions in the extant transportation literature are not IC, thereby scarifying AE. In contrast, the well-known VCG auction (Vickrey, 1961; Clarke, 1971; Groves, 1973) is IC, IR and AE, but fails BB in the bilateral trading environments. Under the standard bilateral VCG auction, the total value of agents (including buyers and sellers) is maximized and each agent pays the “opportunity cost” that she/he introduces to all the others. For a summary and general definition of the VCG mechanism, see Nisan and Ronen (1999). It is well known that no bilateral exchange can be simultaneously AE, BB (even in the ex-ante case), and IR (Myerson and Satterthwaite, 1983). This impossibility theorem is pervasive in the settings with continuous valuations. Othman and Sandholm (2009) are among the first to examine how frequently the impossibility holds over several discrete settings. As a result, this impossibility still holds generally for settings with large number of possible valuations. This result implies that some realistic valuation structures (e.g., structures with small number of possible valuations) may impair the impossibility with high frequency. Despite this, much research has turned to the asymptotically or fairly efficient mechanisms. Parkes et al. (2001) presents a combinatorial exchange mechanism with BB as a hard constraint, which is BB and IR but fairly efficient and fairly IC. In contrast to Parkes et al. (2001), we develop one-sided VCG combinatorial auctions for a complex transportation marketplace with multiple lanes, ensuring IC, IR, AE and BB. Using a different approach, McAfee (1992) proposes a truthful double auction mechanism for a simple exchange environment in which multiple buyers and sellers exchange single units of the same commodity. In addition to IC, this mechanism results in BB, IR, and asymptotical efficiency. This mechanism is usually called McAfee double auction or single-unit trade reduction auction. Under the trade reduction mechanism, the least profitable trade is excluded from an efficient allocation, but the indiscriminate transaction prices are determined by the bidding prices of the agents who are in the least profitable trade. For an excellent review of single-unit trade reduction auction mechanisms, see Babaioff and Nisan (2004). Recently, Gonen et al. (2007) design a generalized trade reduction auction method for single-value agents, realizing IC, IR, and BB with a loss of efficiency. In the single-value models (e.g., McAfee, 1992; Babaioff and Nisan, 2004; Gonen et al., 2007), however, it is not optimal for the players who want to exchange multi-unit items to report their bidding prices truthfully. In this paper, we propose three truthful multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms for TSP in the logistics e-marketplace where there are multiple shippers and carriers, and each of them wants to exchange a bundle of items or a single item. Related to our work, there exist a few studies that explore truthful multi-unit double auctions with different mechanism design methods. Huang et al. (2002) propose an IC and asymptotical efficient trade reduction mechanism for a multi-unit exchange environment with a single type of commodity. In our three multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms, the first mechanism (say, MTR) is related to the method used in Huang et al. (2002). The main differences between them are: (1) the allocation rule in our MTR mechanism is designed specifically for TSP, which is effective for either full-truckload or less-than-truckload situation; (2) we adopt the perturbation technique proposed by Babaioff and Walsh (2005) to break the tie and choose a unique solution; and (3) we view the market broker’s payoff as a part of social welfare. Different from the trade reduction method, Chu and Shen (2008) develop the truthful buyer competition and modified buyer competition double auctions, in which the buying prices are determined by a shadow price method. Chu (2009) proposes a truthful multi-unit double auction with the “padding” method that intentionally generates the imbalances of supply and demand by introducing a dummy buyer with unlimited budget. However, in the bilateral exchange environment, our current focus is on the trade reduction method. Since the exchange prices are determined by the least profitable bidding prices, then no transaction can occur if there is only one buyer or one seller in the trade reduction auction. In this paper, we consider a randomized mechanism that links our proposed one-sided VCG mechanisms and multi-unit trade reduction mechanisms. This randomized mechanism is practical in both the one-sided and bilateral exchange transportation marketplaces, even with the less-than-truckload constraint. 3 Model description Let H denote the set of lanes in a transportation network. Let I denote the set of shippers, and J denote the set of carriers. We refer to a shipper as “she” and a carrier as “he”. Both shippers and carriers are called “agents”. We refer to one truckload of transportation service as “one unit item”. This full-truckload (FTL) assumption is relaxed in the following sections. We use the term “bid” to denote both a shipper’s and a carrier’s declaration. A bid consists of a set of lanes and one bidding price. In a transportation market with m shippers and n carriers, each shipper i(i ∈ I) wants to purchase a bundle of items (or a single item) and each carrier j(j ∈ J) has a bundle of items (or a single item) to sell. We assume both the demand and supply are common knowledge. The same assumption can be found in a number of studies for auction mechanism design, for example, Huang et al. (2002), Lehmann et al. (2002), Babaioff and Walsh (2005), Ledyard (2007), Chu and Shen (2008), and Chu (2009). Let b i be the reservation value of shipper/buyer i, and s j be the reservation value of carrier/seller j. We assume that the reservation value is private knowledge for each agent. Each shipper (carrier) submits one sealed bid b ˆ i ( s ˆ j ) , which may or may not equal to her (his) real valuation. We assume that each agent is a self-interested player who is attempting to maximize her/his own utility. We also assume all the agents have quasi-linear utility. That is, if an agent makes no trade, his or her utility is zero; otherwise, the utility is the difference between the agent’s valuation and the amount of money transferred. The auctioneer’s monetary payoff is the difference between the total payments from the shippers and the total revenues of the carriers. The social welfare is the summation of each agent’s utility and the auctioneer’s payoff. In this study, we define one-sided auction context (called Context A) and double auction context (called Context B) as follows. • Context A: Only the shippers (or the carriers) submit their bids and the “current” optimal output of a one-sided mechanism is derived only based on the shippers’ (or the carriers’) bids. The reservation value enables every agent who does not submit her/his bid to accept or reject the “current” optimal output. Note that, in Context A, the auction is triggered by every unfulfilled demand or extra supply in the transportation market. Thus, there is usually only one agent (or alliance) who does not submit her/his bid when an auction is triggered. This is because that multiple agents without submitting bids will cause conflicts among them, resulting in trade failure. • Context B: Both the shippers and the carriers submit their bids and the “final” optimal output of a bilateral mechanism is derived based on all the agents’ bids. All agents have to accept the “final” optimal output. This paper aims to develop transportation procurement auctions that can realize: (i) all of the four principles (AE, IC, IR, and BB) in Context A; and (ii) IC, IR and BB in Context B. We also pursue asymptotical efficiency (AsE) in Context B. Note that, the abbreviation AE represents allocative efficiency (i.e., maximal social welfare) and the abbreviation AsE represents asymptotical efficiency. AsE means that the market inefficiency under the mechanism compared to AE converges to zero as the number of agents approaches infinity; thus, AE can be realized as the auction becomes large enough (e.g., McAfee, 1992; Huang et al., 2002; Chu, 2009). In Context A, we first consider a one-sided VCG (O-VCG) combinatorial auction. In this auction, there are one shipper and n carriers. Let X h denote the shipper’s demand quantity in lane h (h ∈ H), and Y j h denote the carrier j’s (j ∈ J) supply quantity in lane h. All the carriers submit their “all-or-nothing” bids (atomic bids, see Nisan (2000)). That is, each carrier j sells Y j h unit items in lane h (h ∈ H) if he is involved in the final trade; otherwise, he does not sell any item. We assume the total transportation capacity remains sufficient if any one of the truckers is removed. This is realistic when the transportation market is not very “thin”. The auctioneer calculates the current optimal output by minimizing the total transportation cost. The shipper then accepts or rejects this current optimal output according to her reservation value. Auction O-VCG is an application of VCG-type auction for TSP. We then propose a similar auction (called O-VCGT) in the case of one carrier and m shippers. Both the O-VCG and O-VCGT auctions can realize IC, AE, IR, and BB in Context A, even with the requirement of less-than-truckload (LTL). To demonstrate the necessity of bilateral exchange (Context B) in the case with m shippers and n carriers, we first present a multi-unit trade reduction (MTR) auction for TSP. We assume that every agent values the set of lanes (H) at the sum of the values of its elements (h ∈ H). Since all the ∣H∣ auctions are independent, our TSP problem in Context B is restricted to one fixed lane. That is, we only consider sequential auctions for each lane in Context B. Each shipper i(i ∈ I) wants to purchase X i unit items and each carrier j(j ∈ J) has Y i unit items to sell. All the agents submit their “dividable” bids (OR bids, see Nisan (2000)), implying that every agent is allowed to split her/his volume. The auctioneer clears the transportation market at the critical quantity point where the aggregate supply and demand meet. To involve more agents competing in the final trade, we then propose two MTR-like auction mechanisms: MTR buyer augment (MTR-BA) and MTR seller augment (MTR-SA). Compared to the base MTR mechanism, more buyers/shippers win the “tickets” for competing in the final trade in the MTR-BA mechanism; likewise, more sellers/carriers win these tickets in the MTR-SA mechanism. We found that all the three mechanisms (MTR, MTR-BA, and MTR-SA) are IC, IR, BB, and AsE, with or without the LTL constraint. However, these three mechanisms could result in different expected utility for the agents and the auctioneer. Finally, to capture the tradeoff between the O-VCG and MTR auction classes, we suggest a new randomized auction mechanism called “randomized truthful and efficient (RTE) auction”, which is IC, BB, IR and AsE. Unlike the O-VCG and MTR mechanisms, this RTE mechanism is practical in both Context A and Context B, even under the condition of LTL. 4 O-VCG auctions 4.1 Model In this section, we study Auction O-VCG, where the shipper wants to purchase X h unit items in lane h (h ∈ H), and each carrier j(j ∈ J) submits a bid s ˆ j for supplying Y j h unit items in lane h (h ∈ H). Recall that both X h and Y j h are common knowledge. Given these information, the total transportation cost minimization can be formulated as the following binary integer programming (BIP) problem: (1) P 1 : min ∑ j = 1 n s ˆ j ξ j (2) s . t . ∑ j = 1 n Y j h ξ j ⩾ X h , h ∈ H , (3) ξ j = { 0 , 1 } , j ∈ J , (4) Y j h ⩾ 0 , ∀ h , j , where ξ j denotes whether the carrier j trades in the auction; the objective function (1) is to minimize the sum of the accepted bids; and constraint (2) is to ensure sufficient supply capacity. Indeed, according to Vazirani (2001, p. 108), the winner determination problem of the above BIP belongs to the set covering problem, which is one of Karp’s 21 NP-complete problems (Karp, 1972). The set of items can be treated as “the universe”. Each one unit item represents one unique element of the universe. n bids, { s ˆ 1 } , … , { s ˆ n } , can be treated as n subsets whose union comprises the universe. Then our set covering problem is to select the minimum total cost of the subsets whose union contains all the elements in the universe. Note that, in the unweighted set covering problem, the cost of each subset is one. Nevertheless, BIP is generally solved by the branch-and-bound algorithm or the branch-and-cut algorithm. In particular, the branch-and-cut technique is commonly used for solving the BIPs with many thousand variables, and sometimes even hundreds of thousands of variables (Hillier and Lieberman, 2001). In our case, there is only one type of variables, i.e., binary variables, ξ j (j ∈ J). Hence, the number of these binary variables is n, regardless of ∣H∣. Due to the territorial and temporal restrictions, the number of carriers (n) engaging in an auction is usually not extremely large (e.g., less than a thousand). Alternatively, the auctioneer can restrict the upper bound of n. In practice, one can employ a commercially available optimization package, CPLEX or LINGO, to solve this problem in economically feasible run times. 4.2 Mechanism To induce the carriers to submit their bids truthfully, we next design a one-sided VCG (O-VCG) combinatorial auction mechanism for the problem P1. As shown in the proof of Theorem 1, our O-VCG auction belongs to the VCG family, which induces weak truth-telling from all the carriers (see Theorem 1 and its proof). For a general understanding of the VCG family, we briefly review the notation and definition of Nisan and Ronen (1999) in Appendix A.1. Let π be the optimal value of the objective function (1), and π −j be the optimal value of the objective function if carrier j is excluded from this auction. As presumed in Section 3, the total transportation capacity remains sufficient if any one of the truckers is removed. The shipper will pay carrier j (5) p j = π - j - ( π - s ˆ j ξ j ) , where π −j − π is the bonus payment made to carrier j, standing for the value she contributes to system by engaging in the auction. If ξ j =0, then π −j = π and p j =0. If ξ j =1, the shipper pays carrier j his bid s ˆ j plus his contribution to the system. The total cost of the shipper, TC, is given by (6) TC = ∑ j = 1 n p j = ∑ j = 1 n [ π - j - ( π - s ˆ j ξ j ) ] = ∑ j = 1 n π - j - ( n - 1 ) π . Let b 1 denote the shipper’s reservation price. If TC < b 1, the trade succeeds; otherwise, the trade fails. Under the payment structure of (5), the auctioneer provides an escrow payment service by collecting the total payment, TC, made by the shipper, and delivering p j to carrier j, without transaction costs. Therefore, the auctioneer’s payoff is always zero in Auction O-VCG. Our O-VCG mechanism is summarized as follows: • Collect the demand and supply quantity (X h and Y j h ) from the agents, and collect one sealed bid s ˆ j from each carrier j. • Determine the set of winners by calculating the problem (P1). • Calculate the revenue (p j ) of carrier j based on (P1) and (5). • Calculate the total cost of the shipper (TC) based on (P1) and (6). • If TC < b 1, collect the total payment (TC) made by the shipper, and deliver the payment (p j ) to carrier j; otherwise, the trade fails. 4.3 Properties Theorem 1 The O-VCG mechanism is IC, AE, BB, and IR. All the proofs in this paper are provided in the appendix. By the proof, Auction O-VCG belongs to the VCG family, which induces weak truth-telling (IC) from all the carriers, i.e., s ˆ j = s j . Since the demand quantity is common knowledge, Auction O-VCG is also IC for the shipper. Essentially the VCG mechanism provides a solution for any utilitarian problem with the dominant strategy of IC (Nisan and Ronen, 1999). Based on the property of IC, Auction O-VCG minimizes the total transportation cost and thus realizes AE. In addition, the properties of BB and IR offer an incentive for the agents and the auctioneer to participate in the auction. Let O-VCGT denote a variant of Auction O-VCG. In the O-VCGT auction, there are one carrier and multiple shippers in the transportation marketplace when the auction is triggered. Let m be the number of shippers. The carrier wants to sell Y h unit items in lane h (h ∈ H), and each shipper i(i ∈ I) submits a bid b ˆ i for purchasing X i h unit items in lane h (h ∈ H). Similar to the formulation of Auction O-VCG, the total revenue maximization for the carrier is given as the following BIP problem: (1′) P 1 ′ : max ∑ i = 1 m b ˆ i ξ i (2′) s . t ∑ i = 1 m X i h ξ i ⩽ Y h , h ∈ H , (3′) ξ i = { 0 , 1 } , i ∈ I , (4′) X i h ⩾ 0 , ∀ h , i , where ξ i denotes whether the shipper i trades in the auction; the objective function (1′) is to maximize the sum of the accepted bids; and constraint (2′) is to ensure sufficient supply capacity, similar to constraint (2). It is clear that the winner determination problem of the above BIP (P1′) belongs to the 0–1 knapsack problem, which is one of Karp’s 21 NP-complete problems (Karp, 1972). Using the Vickrey payment structure (see Definition 1 in the appendix), O-VCGT auction has the following proposition. Theorem 2 The O-VCG T mechanism is IC, AE, BB, and IR. Theorem 2 shows that the O-VCG mechanism can be extended to address the case with one carrier and multiple shippers, without changing the properties of IC, AE, BB, and IR. Indeed, the VCG approach can be used to design an optimal mechanism by simply selecting the payment rule that induces weak truth-telling (IC) and the allocation rule that maximizes the sum of values (AE). Since these two mechanisms have the similar allocation rule and payment rule, those four properties (IC, AE, BB, and IR) are shared between Auction O-VCG and Auction O-VCGT. Observation 1 LTL is allowed in the O-VCG auction class, including the O-VCG and O-VCGT mechanisms. Observation 1 can be easily checked by the characteristics of the demand and supply quantity. From the problem (P1) and Eqs. (5) and (6), we find both X h and Y j h are not necessarily full truckloads. Instead, the O-VCG mechanism holds as long as both X h and Y j h are expressed in the same measurement such as kilogram and cubic meter. This result can satisfy some agents’ special requirements. For example, a carrier wants to sell half truckload of transportation service in one lane (say lane 1) and one truckload of transportation service in another lane (say lane 2). In Auction O-VCG, this carrier can simply submit a bid, including one bidding price, 0.5 unit supply quantity in lane 1, and 1 unit supply quantity in lane 2. Hence, the O-VCG mechanism is flexible with respect to the requirements of demand and supply quantity. Similarly, LTL is also allowed in the O-VCGT mechanism. 5 MTR auctions As we stated before, Auction O-VCG will result in trade failure if the total cost of the shipper is larger than her reservation value. Moreover, if the shipper (ex ante) commits to the Vickrey payment structure given in (5), Auction O-VCG will not be IR for the shipper. If the shipper’s reservation price is involved in the objective function of Auction O-VCG, the O-VCG mechanism will fail BB if the auctioneer wants to induce IC; and Auction O-VCG will not be AE if IC is sacrificed. Besides, Auction O-VCG is infeasible in the bilateral exchange environment. The same rationale can be applied to the case of Auction O-VCGT. In this section, we investigate the effective and efficient auction mechanisms for the bilateral exchange environment with multiple shippers and carriers. We first develop a multi-unit trade reduction (MTR) auction under which all the lanes are partitioned into distinct markets. Then we recognized the fact that the agents benefit more from lower indiscriminate trading prices in bilateral exchange environments. As a result, two new MTR-like auctions are proposed in Section 5.5 MTR-BA (buyer augment) and MTR-SA (seller augment). Since all these three mechanisms share the same properties like IC, IR, BB and AsE (asymptotical efficiency), then they are classified into a class of MTR mechanisms. In Section 5.6, we conduct numerical study to compare the efficiencies of these three MTR mechanisms. At the end of this section, a randomized mechanism that integrates both the O-VCG and MTR auction classes is proposed. 5.1 Model Consider the transportation market with one fixed lane, m shippers and n carriers. Each shipper i(i ∈ I) wants to purchase X i unit items and each carrier j(j ∈ J) has Y i unit items to sell. We assume that the agents are allowed to split their volumes. Let q ij denote the quantity the shipper i buys from the carrier j. If all of the agents bid truthfully, the maximal social welfare V(I, J) can be obtained by solving the following linear programming problem: (7) P 2 : max V ( I , J ) = ∑ i = 1 m ∑ j = 1 n q ij ( b i - s j ) (8) s . t . ∑ j = 1 n q ij ⩽ X i , i ∈ I ; (9) ∑ i = 1 m q ij ⩽ Y i , j ∈ J ; (10) q ij ⩾ 0 , ∀ i , j . The constraints (8) and (9) state that a carrier sells no more than what he possesses, and a shipper will not buy more than she needs. Since the social welfare is the summation of the auctioneer’s payoff and each agent’s utility, the trading prices do not show up in the problem (P2). Nonetheless, the trading prices will affect each agent’s utility. If all information is public, the maximal social welfare can be easily obtained by clearing the market. However, this centralized solution is usually not available because agents have their own private reservation values. 5.2 Mechanism To induce the agents to submit their bids truthfully, we design a MTR auction mechanism for this problem. We first construct the supply and demand curves by sorting the carriers’ bids as s ˆ 1 ⩽ s ˆ 2 ⩽ … ⩽ s ˆ n , and the shippers’ bids as b ˆ 1 ⩾ b ˆ 2 ⩾ … ⩾ b ˆ m . The market is cleared at the critical quantity point Q ∗ where the aggregate supply and demand are balanced, leading to b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L and b ˆ K + 1 < s ˆ L + 1 (see Fig. 1 ). In Fig. 1, we have Q ∗ = min ∑ 1 K X i , ∑ 1 L Y j (the total trade quantity in the maximal social welfare), Q ′ = min ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j (the total trade quantity realized by the MTR mechanism), and Q ″ = min ∑ 1 K + 1 X i , ∑ 1 L + 1 Y j . The efficiency loss is shown in the shadow area W. In case of multiple optimal solutions, a perturbation technique proposed by Babaioff and Walsh (2005) is adopted to break the tie and select a unique optimal solution. A perturbation factor ε is added into each agent’s bid. We treat their bids as b ˆ i + ε i and s ˆ j + ε j instead of b ˆ i and s ˆ j for each shipper and carrier, where 1≫ ε 1,I ≫ ε 2,I ≫…≫ ε m,I ⩾ ε 1,J ≫ ε 2,J ≫…≫ ε n,J >0. Then the problem (P2) with perturbation factors has one unique solution. Since ε ≪1, this solution indeed is an efficient allocation under original bids. Observation 2 There are three market clearing situations. Case (I). ∑ i = 1 K X i = ∑ j = 1 L Y j ; Case (II). ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j < ∑ i = 1 K X i < ∑ j = 1 L Y j , b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L > b ˆ K + 1 ; Case (III). ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i < ∑ j = 1 L Y j < ∑ i = 1 K X i , s ˆ L + 1 > b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L . Based on the fact that b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L and b ˆ K + 1 < s ˆ L + 1 , it is easy to prove Observation 2. Note that, in Case I, there are four circumstances: ( b ˆ K > s ˆ L + 1 , b ˆ K + 1 < s ˆ L ) , ( b ˆ K > s ˆ L + 1 , b ˆ K + 1 > s ˆ L ) , ( b ˆ K < s ˆ L + 1 , b ˆ K + 1 < s ˆ L ) , and ( b ˆ K < s ˆ L + 1 , b ˆ K + 1 > s ˆ L ) . Our MTR mechanism can address all those three scenarios (Case I, Case II and Case III). To clear the market, we check whether inequality (11) ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j or (12) ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i ⩽ ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j holds. Actually, (11) and (12) imply an excess of demand and an oversupply, respectively. If (11) holds, we use the following rule. Rule 1: Step 1: All the carriers with indices j < L sell their volume Y j at the indiscriminate price s ˆ L . Step 2(a): All the shippers with indices i < K trade at the indiscriminate price b ˆ K . The auctioneer ranks all the trading shippers (i < K) according to the amount of their demands, and a greater demand of one shipper leads to a higher ranking for this shipper. Step 2(b): A perturbation technique is used to break the tie if some shippers’ demands are equal. Let r i ′ denote the ranking of the shipper i′. Note that, the shipper i′ is not equivalent to the shipper i. Then all the trading shippers’ rankings are aligned in a strongly ascending order: r 1 ′ < r 2 ′ < … < r ( K - 1 ) ′ . Step 3: Let fix(x) denote the maximal integer that is not larger than x. Each shipper i′ at least gets a “basic” volume q ¯ i ′ = fix X i ′ ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j ∑ i ′ = 1 ′ ( K - 1 ) ′ X i ′ , where q ¯ i ′ ⩽ X i ′ and ∑ i ′ = 1 ′ ( K - 1 ) ′ X i ′ = ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i . The remaining supply is ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j - ∑ i = 1 K - 1 q ¯ i , which is an integer. Let RS = ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j - ∑ i = 1 K - 1 q ¯ i . This remaining supply (RS) is distributed among all the trading shippers according to their rankings and demands. Let q i ′ denote the volume obtained by the shipper i′. Then, q i ′ is expressed as (13) q i ′ = min X i ′ , q ¯ i ′ + RS - ∑ a ′ = ( i + 1 ) ′ ( K - 1 ) ′ ( q a ′ - q ¯ a ′ ) , 1 ′ ⩽ i ′ ⩽ ( K - 2 ) ′ min { X ( K - 1 ) ′ , q ¯ ( K - 1 ) ′ + RS } , i ′ = ( K - 1 ) ′ Note that, q i ′ is an integer, and q ¯ i ′ ⩽ q i ′ ⩽ X i ′ .□ If (12) holds, we follow Rule 2. Rule 2: Step 1: All the shippers with indices i < K get their volume X i at price b ˆ K . Step 2(a): All the carriers with indices j < L trade at price s ˆ L . The auctioneer ranks all those carriers (j < L) based on the amount of their supplies, and the larger supply of one carrier is, the higher ranking for this carrier. Step 2(b): Let r j ′ denote the ranking of the carrier j′. By using a perturbation technique, all the trading carriers’ rankings are displayed in a strongly ascending order: r 1 ′ < r 2 ′ < … < r ( L - 1 ) ′ . Step 3: Each carrier j′ at least sells a “basic” volume q ¯ j ′ = fix Y j ′ ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j , where q ¯ j ′ ⩽ Y j ′ . The remaining demand is given by RD = ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i - ∑ j = 1 L - 1 q ¯ j . This remaining demand (RS) is distributed among all the trading carriers according to their rankings and supplies. Let q j ′ denote the sales volume of the carrier j′. Then, q j ′ is expressed as (14) q j ′ = min Y j ′ , q ¯ j ′ + RD - ∑ b ′ = ( j + 1 ) ′ ( L - 1 ) ′ q b ′ - q ¯ b ′ , 1 ′ ⩽ j ′ ⩽ ( L - 2 ) ′ min Y ( L - 1 ) ′ , q ¯ ( L - 1 ) ′ + RD , j ′ = ( L - 1 ) ′ where q j ′ is an integer, and q ¯ j ′ ⩽ q j ′ ⩽ Y j ′ .□ Both Rule 1 and Rule 2 ensure that each agent’s trade quantity (i.e., q i ′ and q j ′ ) is full truckloads, even though the agents are allowed to split their volumes. The total trading volume is min ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i , ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j . The auctioneer takes the total trade surplus (15) ( b ˆ K - b ˆ L ) ∗ min ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i , ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j . Note that, for the sake of readability, in the following we do not restate the introduction of the perturbation technique that can be used to break the tie and choose a unique solution. Our MTR mechanism is therefore summarized as follows: • Collect one sealed bid from each agent. • Sorting the carriers’ bids as s ˆ 1 < s ˆ 2 < … < s ˆ n , and the shippers’ bids as b ˆ 1 > b ˆ 2 > … > b ˆ m . • Clear the market at the critical quantity point Q ∗ where b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L and b ˆ K + 1 < s ˆ L + 1 . • Remove all the agents who are not involved in the trade (i.e., shippers with indices i ⩾ K and all the carriers with indices j ⩾ L). • Follow Rule 1 if (11) holds; otherwise, follow Rule 2. 5.3 Example The best way to understand the MTR mechanism is through a simple example (see Table 1 ). In this example, K = L = 4 , b ˆ K = 9 , s ˆ L = 6 , and Case (I) holds. Since ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i = 19 > ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j = 13 , inequality (11) holds and the trade quantity is 13. By using Rule 1, we derive each shipper’s basic volume: q ¯ 1 ′ = fix 9 ∗ 13 19 = 6 (for shipper 1), q ¯ 2 ′ = fix 6 ∗ 13 19 = 4 (for shipper 3), and q ¯ 3 ′ = fix 4 ∗ 13 19 = 2 (for shipper 2). This remaining supply is given by RS = ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j - ∑ i = 1 K - 1 q ¯ i = 1 . We then calculate the volume obtained by the shipper with the highest ranking (i.e., shipper 1): q 1 ′ = min { 6 + RS , X 1 ′ } = 7 . Since all the remaining supply is allocated to shipper 1, then q 2 ′ = q ¯ 2 ′ = 4 and q 3 ′ = q ¯ 3 ′ = 2 . 5.4 Properties Theorem 3 The MTR mechanism is IC with respect to reservation price, BB, and IR. Theorem 3 shows that the MTR mechanism is effective in terms of the agents’ truthful biddings and the incentives to participate, even though it fails AE. Since we focus on simplifying the agents’ bidding strategy by ensuring IC, efficiency loss is inevitable in the bilateral exchange with BB and IR. Observation 3 LTL is allowed in the MTR mechanism. Although both the Rule 1 and Rule 2 in the MTR mechanism ensure that each agent can only sell or buy full truckloads of transportation services, we could extend the MTR mechanism to the LTL case. Indeed, the auctioneer can define a feasible lowest threshold such that all the volumes that are below this threshold will not be considered, and the volumes that are not multiples of this threshold’s value will be adjusted electronically. For example, this threshold is defined as 10% truckload (1 unit), then the volume of 8% truckload will be removed, and the demand volume of 15% truckload could be treated as 20% (2 units). On the contrary, the supply volume of 15% truckload could be treated as 10%. Clearly, this treatment will not influence the properties of IC, IR, and BB. Also, this treatment is efficient if the threshold is low enough. We next evaluate the efficiency performance of the MTR mechanism. In a bilateral exchange market, the payoff taken by the market maker is usually viewed as a part of social welfare (e.g., McAfee, 1992; Chu and Shen, 2008). McAfee (1992) demonstrates that a single-unit trade reduction auction is AsE (asymptotically efficient). Using the same definition, we show that our MTR mechanism is also AsE. We assume that X i , i =1,…,m, the shippers’ volumes, are independent random samples following the distribution of a random variable X; and Y j , j =1,…,n, the carriers’ volumes, are independent random samples following the distribution of a random variable Y. Assume 0< E[X], E[Y]<∞, where E is the expectation operator. Assume that both the shippers’ and carriers’ bidding prices are in the same compact interval [p −, p +], where 0< p − < p + <∞. This assumption is more realistic when there are a large number of participators in the auction. For analytical tractability, we further assume that both the shippers’ and carriers’ bidding prices are drawn independently from the standard uniform distribution F with density function f in [0,1]. Note that, each agent’s bidding price is treated as the form of x ˆ - p - p + - p - , where x ˆ represents the original bidding price. As shown in Fig. 1, the efficiency loss, W(K, L), can be expressed as (16) W ( K , L ) = ( Q ∗ - Q ′ ) ( b K - s L ) + Δ , where (Q ∗ − Q′)(b K − s L ) is the auctioneer’s efficiency loss, and Δ is the agents’ efficiency loss. The maximal social welfare, V(K, L), is expressed as (17) V ( K , L ) = ( b K - s L ) Q ∗ + ∑ 1 K ( b i - b K ) X i + ∑ 1 L ( s L - s j ) Y j , where (b K − s L )Q ∗ is the auctioneer’s payoff, ∑ 1 K ( b i - b K ) X i is the shippers’ efficiency, and ∑ 1 L ( s L - s j ) Y j is the carriers’ efficiency. Given K and L, the inefficiency ratio of the MTR mechanism, λ(K, L), can be given by (18) λ ( K , L ) = E [ W ( K , L ) ] E [ V ( K , L ) ] . Observation 4 If (11) holds, Δ <(b 1 − b K )Y L ; otherwise, Δ < (s L − s 1)X K . It is easy to check Observation 4 based on Observation 1 and inequalities (11) and (12). Observation 4 means that the agents’ efficiency loss is bounded. Lemma 2 (1) E [ b i - b k ] = k - i m + 1 ( p + - p - ) , 1 ⩽ i < k ⩽ m ; (2) E [ s l - s j ] = l - j n + 1 ( p + - p - ) , 1 ⩽ l < j ⩽ n . Lemma 2 implies that the expected interval between any two variates within the same order statistics depends only on the difference between their order numbers, not on each order number individually. As shown in Lemma 2 (1), the expected interval between b i and b k , E[b i − b k ], depends only on k − i = (m − i)− (m − k), where (m − i) is the order number of b i and (m − k) is the order number of b k . Based on Lemma 2, we can derive the following theorem. Theorem 4 λ(K, L) ⩽ O(max{1/K,1/L}). Theorem 4 says that when the number of agents who trade finally is large, the market inefficiency converges to zero at the rate of max {1/K,1/L}. For the detailed results, readers can refer to the appendix. Theorem 5 The MTR mechanism is AsE, in the sense that λ(K, L) → 0 if K and L approach infinity as m and n approach infinity. Theorem 5 can be easily checked by Theorem 4, the proof is thus omitted. Theorem 5 indicates that if the number of agents who successfully trade approaches infinity, the ratio between the realized social welfare and maximal social welfare goes to 100%. Our MTR mechanism is therefore AsE. If K and L approach infinity, then the total trade volume and thus the maximal social welfare must be infinite. By Theorem 5, we can further conclude that if K and L approach infinity, the social welfare realized by the MTR mechanism must be infinite. 5.5 Variants of MTR mechanism We define the first variant of the MTR mechanism as “MTR buyer augment (MTR-BA) mechanism” and the other as “MTR seller augment (MTR-SA) mechanism”. Recall that in the MTR mechanism, the auctioneer first chooses the candidates for the final trade only based on the bidding prices, and next matches the demand and supply among these candidates according to their rankings, which are independent with their bidding prices. We say an agent who is selected at the first stage wins a “ticket” for competing in the final trade. Compared to the base MTR mechanism, more buyers/shippers win the “tickets” for competing in the final trade in the MTR-BA mechanism; likewise, more sellers/carriers win these tickets in the MTR-SA mechanism. The MTR-BA mechanism is similar to the MTR mechanism, except that K + shippers and L carriers win the “tickets”, where K + ⩾ K, and b K ⩾ b K + ⩾ s L > b K + + 1 . The trade prices of the MTR-BA mechanism are b K + and s L . In the example shown in Table 1, we have K +(=5)> K(=4) and s L ( = 6 ) > b K + + 1 ( = 5 ) . In the MTR-SA mechanism, K shippers and L + carriers win the “tickets”, where L + ⩾ L, and s L + + 1 > b K ⩾ b L + ⩾ s L . The MTR-SA mechanism’s trade prices are b K and s L + . Let Q BA denote the trade quantity of the MTR-BA mechanism, and Q SA denote the trade quantity of the MTR-SA mechanism. It is clear that Q BA = min ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i , ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j and Q SA = min ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , ∑ 1 L + - 1 Y j , each of which is not less than Q ′ = min ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j (the trade quantity of the MTR mechanism). The allocation rules of these two variants can be summarized as follows: If ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j , then the MTR-BA mechanism follows Rule 1 where K is replaced by K +; otherwise, the MTR-BA mechanism follows Rule 2 where K is replaced by K +. Similarly, if ∑ 1 K - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L + - 1 Y j , then the MTR-SA mechanism follows Rule 1 where L is replaced by L +; otherwise, the MTR-SA mechanism follows Rule 2 where L is replaced by L +. As shown in Observation 2, there are three market clearing situations (Case-I, Case-II, and Case-III) in the MTR mechanism. The following observation is stated based on these three cases. Observation 5 (1) If ∑ i = 1 K X i = ∑ j = 1 L Y j (Case-I), then K + ⩾ K and L + ⩾ L. (2) If ∑ j = 1 L - 1 Y j < ∑ i = 1 K X i < ∑ j = 1 L Y j (Case-II), then K + = K and L + ⩾ L. (3) If ∑ i = 1 K - 1 X i < ∑ j = 1 L Y j < ∑ i = 1 K X i (Case-III), then L + = L and K + ⩾ K. It is easy to prove Observation 5 based on Observation 2. The proof is thus omitted. Observation 5-(1) shows that in Case (I), both the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms could be adopted in addition to the MTR mechanism. Observation 5-(2) shows that in Case (II), the MTR-BA mechanism is equivalent to the MTR mechanism, but the MTR-SA mechanism could be another option. Similarly, Observation 5–(3) shows that in Case (III), the MTR-SA mechanism is equivalent to the MTR mechanism, but the MTR-BA mechanism could be another choice. Theorem 6 The MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms are IC, BB, and IR. Theorem 6 shows that both the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms can be implemented as well as the MTR mechanism with respect to IC, BB, and IR. In addition, Theorem 6 implies that the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms are not AE, the same as the MTR mechanism. However, the efficiency performance of the MTR-BA (MTR-SA) mechanism cannot be evaluated by using Lemma 4 and simply replacing K(L) by K +(L +). In the McAfee (1992)’s single-unit double auction and the class of our MTR mechanisms, the maximal social welfare (AE) means the maximal market value counted at the point where the demand and supply are balanced. This is a common definition about AE and has been adopted by a number of studies for auction mechanism design (e.g., McAfee, 1992; Huang et al., 2002; Chu and Shen, 2008). Therefore, the maximal social welfare is always V(K, L), given in (17), which depends only on K and L. In the following, we investigate the inefficiency ratio of the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms. We simply focus on the MTR-BA mechanism because these two variants are similar. According to Observation 5, the MTR-BA mechanism is equivalent to the MTR mechanism in the scenario of ∑ i = 1 K X i < ∑ j = 1 L Y j . Thus, we simply investigate the scenario with ∑ i = 1 K X i ⩾ ∑ j = 1 L Y j and K + > K. In the MTR-BA mechanism, the auctioneer’s efficiency loss, Δ 1, can be written as (19) Δ 1 = ( b K - s L ) Q ∗ - ( b K + - s L ) Q BA . Since Q ∗ = min ∑ 1 K X i , ∑ 1 L Y j = ∑ 1 L Y j , and Q BA = min ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i , ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j = ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j , then (19) is transformed into (20) Δ 1 = ( b K - s L ) ∑ 1 L Y j - ( b K + - s L ) ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j . Let Δ 2 denote the agents’ efficiency loss. Since ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 K X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j , then (21) Δ 2 = ∑ 1 K ( b i - b K ) X i + ∑ 1 L ( s L - s j ) Y j - ∑ 1 K + - 1 b i - b K + q i BA + ∑ 1 L - 1 ( s L - s j ) Y j = ∑ 1 K - 1 ( b i - b K ) X i - ∑ 1 K + - 1 b i - b K + q i BA , where q i BA is determined by Rule 1 where K is replaced by K +. Let W ∼ ( K , K + , L ) denote the total inefficiency loss, and λ ˜ ( K , K + , L ) denote the inefficiency ratio. Then, λ ˜ ( K , K + , L ) is expressed as (22) λ ˜ ( K , K + , L ) = E [ W ∼ ( K , K + , L ) ] E [ V ( K , L ) ] , where W ∼ ( K , K + , L ) = Δ 1 + Δ 2 . Theorem 7 (1) Assume K + − K <∞. The MTR-BA mechanism is AsE. That is, λ ˜ ( K , K + , L ) → 0 if K and L approach infinity as m and n approach infinity. (2) Assume L + − L <∞. The MTR-SA mechanism is AsE. Theorem 7 says that under the condition of K + − K <∞ and L + − L <∞, both the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms can realize the maximal social welfare if the number of agents who successfully trade goes to infinity. Indeed, it is realistic to satisfy the condition of K + − K <∞ and L + − L <∞. In the MTR-BA mechanism, it is clear that s L ⩽ b K and s L + 1 ⩾ b K + + 1 ; that is, s L + 1 - s L ⩾ b K + + 1 - b K . According to Lemma 2, we obtain K + - K ⩽ 1 + m + 1 n + 1 ; and similarly, L + - L ⩽ 1 + n + 1 m + 1 . Thus, if O(n)= O(m), then K + − K <∞ and L + − L <∞. In the MTR-BA mechanism, there is a tradeoff for the auctioneer between an increase in the trade volumes (Q BA ⩾ Q′) and a decline in the profitability b K + - s L ⩽ b K - s L . If K + monotonically increases such that the difference between b K + and s L goes to zero, then the auctioneer’s payoff converges to zero. Hence, the inefficiency ratio might not asymptotically go to zero if the difference between K and K + is not bounded. On the contrary, more shippers could win the “tickets” for competing in the final trade, leading to a lower indiscriminate exchange price b K + ⩽ b K for them. Although a part of the supply volumes may be allocated to the shippers with relatively low values (i = K,…,K + −1), the total expected utility of the shippers becomes larger. More generally, our following theorem suggests that both the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms can bring greater expected utility for the shippers and carriers. Theorem 8 Under the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms, both the shippers’ and carriers’ expected utility are larger than those in the MTR mechanism. Theorem 8 shows that from the agents’ perspective, the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms are better off than the MTR mechanism. However, as we discussed before, the auctioneer may suffer from the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms compared to the MTR mechanism. In the following, we use numerical experiment to study these three MTR mechanisms. 5.6 Numerical study The numerical experiment consists of a single origin–destination network for which a series of shipments (to be transported from origin to destination) is auctioned via MTR mechanisms. There are multiple carriers competing for the shipments provided by multiple shippers. The vehicles’ depots are located in the origin. Auctions are performed one at a time as shipments and transportation capacities arrive at the logistic e-marketplace. This logistic e-marketplace enables the sale of transportation capacity mainly on the basis of price, yet it still meets customer level of service requirements (e.g., hard time windows). The auctions operate periodically, and the cumulated volumes and prices reflect the status of demand and supply. Then the logistic e-marketplace, as the third-party auctioneer, clears the transportation market through a specific MTR auction mechanism. Without loss of generality, consider a transportation market where there are more shippers than the carriers, but the average supply quantity is larger than the average demand quantity. Formally, we assume that X i (i =1,…,m) follows the discrete uniform distribution in the interval [1,3], and Y j (j =1,…,n) follows the discrete uniform distribution in the interval [1,5]. To overlap the agents’ bids, we further assume that b i (i =1,…,m) follows the continuous uniform distribution in the interval [6,11], and s j (j =1,…,n) follows the continuous uniform distribution in the interval [5,10]. That is, in this experiment, we relax the assumption that all the agents’ bidding prices are in the same pool. All the variables are mutually independent. In a real-life application, these arrival volume and price distributions need to be estimated. In such cases, the logistic e-marketplace must work with the estimated distributions based on historic data, and a larger amount of information revealed can result in the estimated distributions with higher quality. Each pair (m, n) ranges from (m =20, n =10) to (m =100, n =50) with the equivalent interval (20,10). For each pair (m, n), we run four exchange mechanisms (MTR, MTR-BA, MTR-SA and AE) to obtain the total market value, the auctioneer’ payoff, the agents’ utility, the shippers’ utility and the carriers’ utility. We repeat these activities 10,000 times and report their average values. Note that, (i) AE (allocative efficiency) represents the maximal social welfare, expressed in (17); (ii) the agents’ utility is the summation of the shippers’ utility and the carriers’ utility; and (iii) the total market value is the summation of the agents’ utility and the auctioneer’s payoff. All the three MTR mechanisms are compared to AE/maximal social welfare. For simplicity, we use BA (SA) to represent the MTR-BA (MTR-SA) mechanism in Tables 2–6 . As shown in Table 2, as the number of the participants (m, n) increases, the number of traders (K, L, K +, L +) increases monotonically as expected. Also, the inefficiency ratio of each MTR mechanism converges to zero as the number of the agents increases, which is consistent with Theorems 5 and 7. When the pair (m, n) is low (m =20, n =10), the inefficiency ratio ranges from 7.39% to 12.44%. As the pair (m, n) increases to (100,50), the inefficiency ratio obviously decreases and ranges from 0.97% to 2.47%. However, it seems that the MTR mechanism can realize higher market value than the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms. This is for the reason that the auctioneer’s payoff is significantly reduced in the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms compared to the MTR mechanism as shown in Table 3. For example, the auctioneer’s payoff loss ratio in the MTR-BA mechanism ranges from 70.66% to 72.94%, whereas in the MTR mechanism its payoff loss ratio is kept in a low range (i.e., from 2.96% to 12.61%). In the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms, more intense competitions lead to lower exchange prices for shippers and carriers, and thus a lower bid-ask spread for the auctioneer. Although there are more winners in the alternative MTR mechanisms, the decreased bid-ask spread results in fewer payoffs for the auctioneer. In Table 4, it seems especially true that the expected utility of the agents is higher in the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms than that in the MTR mechanism, even if the agents’ bidding prices are not in the same pool. This result is probably an extension of Theorem 8 in which the same bidding pool is required. Furthermore, our experiment shows that, the agents’ expected utility in the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms is even higher than that in the AE case. This can be interpreted analytically in some cases. For example, in the MTR-BA mechanism, if ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j ⩾ ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , then the more beneficial indiscriminate exchange prices b K + , s L and larger trade volumes ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j leading to higher utility for the agents. Note that, according to (17), in the AE case, the shippers who have positive utility buy ∑ 1 K - 1 X i units of transportation services, and the carriers who have positive utility sell ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j units of transportation services. However, the efficient trade volumes in the MTR-BA mechanism are ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j . Hence, if ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j ⩾ ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , then the agents’ expected utility in the MTR-BA mechanism is higher than that in the AE case. Tables 5 and 6 indicate some interesting points. First, as stated in Theorem 8, both the MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms can generate higher expected utility for the shippers and carriers compared to the MTR mechanism. Moreover, as expected, the shippers’ (carriers’, respectively) expected utility in the MTR-SA (MTR-BA, respectively) mechanism is lower than that in the AE case. For the shippers, this is because the trade quantity in the MTR-SA mechanism is always not larger than the efficient demand quantity ∑ 1 K - 1 X i in the AE case. The reason for the carriers is similar. However, it seems that MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms could lead to higher expected utilities for shippers and carriers respectively than social welfare maximization. This can be interpreted analytically in some cases. For example, if ∑ 1 K + - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j ⩾ ∑ 1 K - 1 X i , then the shippers’ expected utility in the MTR-BA mechanism is higher than that in the AE case. Similarly, if ∑ 1 L + - 1 Y j ⩾ ∑ 1 K - 1 X i ⩾ ∑ 1 L - 1 Y j , then the MTR-SA mechanism is more beneficial for the carriers, even compared to the AE case. Therefore, the MTR-BA mechanism likely attracts more shippers to engage in the auction, while the carriers possibly prefer to participate in the MTR-SA auction. From the auction platform’s perspective, the MTR mechanism is more profitable but might not in the long term. This illustrates the importance of the auction mechanism selection for TSP. 5.7 Randomized auction mechanism The class of the MTR mechanisms is effective in the bilateral exchange environment (Context B) rather than the one-sided exchange environment (Context A), whereas the class of the O-VCG mechanisms (including the O-VCGT mechanism) is effective in Context A rather than Context B. To capture the tradeoff between these two auction classes, we suggest a new randomized auction mechanism called “randomized truthful and efficient (RTE) auction”, which is IC, BB, IR and AsE (see Theorem 9). Unlike the O-VCG and MTR mechanisms, the RTE mechanism is practical in both Context A and Context B. The RTE mechanism moves as follow: • If there are multiple carriers and one shipper (respectively, multiple shippers and one carrier) in the transportation market, then use the O-VCG (respectively, O-VCGT) mechanism. • If there are multiple shippers and carriers in the transportation market, then use one of the MTR mechanisms (i.e., MTR mechanism, MTR-BA mechanism or MTR-SA mechanism). In this case, one of the MTR mechanisms is predetermined and known for each agent. This RTE mechanism is actually an efficient integration of our proposed O-VCG mechanisms and MTR mechanisms. However, we should notice two points. First, to induce weak truth-telling from shippers and carriers, one of the MTR mechanisms must be predetermined (ex ante determined). An illustrative example is given below Theorem 9. Second, as shown in the proof of Theorem 9, this randomized mechanism largely depends on the IR property of the O-VCG mechanisms and MTR mechanisms. In addition, since the O-VCG mechanisms and MTR mechanisms share some good properties like IC, IR, BB, and AsE, the randomized mechanism is indeed simplified to some extent. Theorem 9 The RTE mechanism is IC, BB, IR and AsE. By Theorem 9, the RTE mechanism that integrates both the O-VCG and MTR auction classes is effective in terms of IC, BB, IR and AsE. Note that, if one of the MTR auction approaches in the RTE mechanism is ex post determined by the maximal market value, then the RTE mechanism is not IC. For example, in Fig. 2 , the shipper i =4 with her reservation price b 4 =9 and demand quantity X 4 =5, can obtain ex post positive utility in the MTR-BA mechanism by overbidding (e.g., bidding price=100) which results in the MTR-BA mechanism’s market value greater than those of the other mechanisms; however, her utility is zero if she reports truthfully in the MTR mechanism. Table 7 summarizes the properties of the proposed transportation procurement auctions proposed in this study. As shown in Table 7, each mechanism designed in this paper ensures IC, IR, BB, and AsE, and can be used for either FTL (full-truckload) or LTL. TFP means trade failure possibility. Since the shipper’s (carrier’s) reservation price is not ex ante involved in Auction O-VCG (O-VCGT), the O-VCG mechanisms have higher TFP than the MTR mechanisms. If AE must be ensured for every execution of an IC and BB mechanism, then O-VCG mechanism should be used. This means the auction is triggered by every unfulfilled demand or extra supply in the transportation market. If the mechanism is expected to be non NP-hard, then one of the MTR auctions (i.e., MTR auction, MTR-BA auction, or MTR-SA auction) is the mechanism of choice. This means the auction is implemented only if there are multiple shippers and carriers in the transportation market. Finally, if one cares about the mechanism effectiveness in both the one-sided and bilateral environments, then the RTE mechanism should be the option. 6 Conclusions In this paper, we aim to develop truthful multi-unit transportation procurement auctions for logistics e-marketplaces. This paper is among the first efforts that incorporate bilateral bidding into mechanism design for transportation procurement. Using insights from the well-known VCG auction (Vickrey, 1961; Clarke, 1971; Groves, 1973), we first introduce a class of one-sided VCG combinatorial auctions (including O-VCG and O-VCGT) for a complex transportation marketplace with multiple lanes. In Auction O-VCG, one shipper and multiple carriers are considered. The objective of Auction O-VCG is to minimize the total transportation cost of carriers. We then propose a symmetric auction (i.e., O-VCGT) with one carrier and multiple shippers and maximize the total revenue of shippers. Under the class of O-VCG auctions, truth telling is an optimal bidding strategy for each agent. Furthermore, these O-VCG auctions can realize AE, IR and BB, with or without the LTL constraint. To illustrate the necessity of bilateral exchange with multiple shippers and carriers, we first develop a multi-unit trade reduction (MTR) auction under which all the lanes are partitioned into distinct markets. Our MTR auction is an extension of the classic single-unit trade reduction mechanism (McAfee, 1992). Unlike the class of O-VCG auctions, both shippers and carriers submit their dividable/OR bids in Auction MTR. Based on the submitted OR bids, the auctioneer clears the transportation market. A practical implication from this research finding is that the agents benefit more from lower indiscriminate trading prices in bilateral exchange environments. As a result, two new MTR-like auctions are proposed: MTR-BA (buyer augment) and MTR-SA (seller augment), for practical applications. Compared to the base MTR mechanism, more buyers/shippers win the “tickets” for competing in the final trade in the MTR-BA mechanism; likewise, more sellers/carriers win these tickets in the MTR-SA mechanism. All the three MTR mechanisms are able to ensure IC, IR, BB and AsE, even under the condition of LTL. Under the buyer and seller augment mechanisms, both shippers’ and carriers’ expected utilities are higher than those in the base MTR mechanism. Numerical study further shows that MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms lead to higher expected utilities for shippers and carriers respectively than social welfare maximization. However, the base MTR mechanism provides a higher payoff to the market broker than MTR-BA and MTR-SA mechanisms. Finally, to capture the tradeoff between the O-VCG and MTR auction classes, we propose a randomized auction mechanism which is still IC, BB, IR and AsE. Moreover, this randomized mechanism is practical in both one-sided and bilateral exchange transportation marketplaces, even with the LTL constraint. An important practical implication here is that the logistic e-marketplace could operate this randomized mechanism to better realize transportation market efficiency and to eliminate the limitations of a single fixed mechanism. It is worth noting the generality of the conditions under which the above results are valid. As shown in our numerical study, the same results hold when the ranges of shippers’ and carriers’ bidding prices are only partially overlapped. This generality suggests a robustness of the results in the sense that the above conclusions are expected to be valid for most transportation markets with MTR auction mechanisms, and that they are not critically dependent on the model we have used for analysis. Our numerical analysis also demonstrates the importance of the auction mechanism selection for TSP. The MTR-BA mechanism possibly attracts more shippers to engage in the auction, while the carriers likely prefer to participate in the MTR-SA auction. In a real-life application, the higher the market efficiency is, the more likely an auction mechanism is to yield higher revenues for the third-party marketplace in the long run (Wise and Morrison, 2000). Therefore, a key managerial implication is that the logistic e-marketplace could choose the MTR-BA or MTR-SA mechanism to realize higher market efficiency in the long term. This work can be extended along several directions. As far as the proposed models are concerned, the demand quantity and supply quantity are common knowledge in this paper. Hence, an extension of this work can be devoted to relax this assumption. However, in such complicated cases, it would be very difficult to ensure some important auction properties such as IC and BB. As for practical applications of the proposed models, it is of paramount importance to investigate these auction mechanisms further under a real-time e-logistics environment with intensive ICT (information and communication technology) enablers. Events and disturbances (e.g. new job arrivals, breakdowns of equipment, early or late availability of goods) are captured on a real-time basis to reduce uncertainty. It is also desirable to investigate how such auctions are conducted and repeated periodically considering real-time disturbances. Appendix A A.1 VCG mechanism For a general treatment of the generalized VCG mechanism, we follow the notation and definition of Nisan and Ronen (1999). We briefly review them here and explain how they relate to our problem. Consider a mechanism design problem, which is given by an output specification and a set of agents’ valuations. Suppose that there are N agents. Each agent i has some private input θ i , termed its true type. Everything else in this mechanism design problem is public knowledge. In this scenario, each agent’s strategy is to report its virtual type t i , which may or may not be its true type. A mechanism maps the inputs, a type vector t =(t 1,…,t N ), into an output o satisfying the output specification, o ∈ O. Each agent i’s preference is given by a real-valued function in terms of some common currency: v i (t i ,o), called its virtual valuation. If the mechanism hands p i units of currency to agent i, then agent i’s net utility will be u i = p i + r i (θ i ), where r i (θ i ) is its real valuation. Note that, r i (θ i ) is private knowledge independent of the mechanism’s output o, whereas the function r i (·) is public knowledge. The net utility u i is what the agent i tries to optimize. A mechanism m = (o,p) consists of two elements: an output function o(t), and an n-tuple of payments (p 1(t),…,p N (t)). We denote (t 1,…,t i−1,t i+1,…,t N ) by t −i , and thus t = (t i ,t −i ). Definition 1 A mechanism m = (o, p) belongs to the VCG family if (A.1) ( 1 ) o ( t ) ∈ arg max o ∑ i = 1 N v i ( t i , o ( t ) ) , and (A.2) ( 2 ) p i ( t ) = h i ( t - i ) + ∑ j ≠ i v j ( t j , o ( t ) ) , where h i (t −i ) is an arbitrary function of t −i , and p i (t) is called agent i’s Vickrey payments. Lemma 1 Groves, 1973 The VCG mechanism is IC. That is, the dominant strategy for agent i is to report its true information θ i if other agents reports truthfully. The proof of Lemma 1 follows standard VCG proofs, for example see Groves (1973) and Krishna (2002).□ A.2 Proof of Theorem 1 In the O-VCG auction, only the carriers could receive Vickrey payments. If TC < b 1, the auctioneer simply collects the total payment made by the shipper and distributes it among the carriers. In other words, this system’s total revenue equals to its total expenditure. If TC ⩾ b 1, there is no trade. Thus, Auction O-VCG is BB. Based on the notation and definition of Nisan and Ronen (1999), we will next prove that Auction O-VCG is IC. Since the demand quantity is common knowledge, Auction O-VCG is IC for the shipper. For carrier j, we have θ j = s ˆ j , t j = s j , o = π , v j ( t j , o ) = - s ˆ j ξ j , r j ( θ j ) = - s j , h j ( t - j ) = π - j . Thus, p j ( t ) = h j ( t - j ) + ∑ j ′ ≠ j v j ′ ( t j ′ , o ( t ) ) = π - j - ( π - s ˆ j ξ j ) . Auction O-VCG is AE because it minimizes the total transportation cost based on the agents’ weak truth telling (IC). The trade occurs if and only if TC < b 1, ensuring IR for the shipper. With the proof of IC, Auction O-VCGT is also AE since it maximizes the total revenue for the carrier.□ A.4 Proof of Theorem 3 We first prove for the scenario where inequality (11) holds. In scenario (11), the MTR mechanism follows Rule 1. The proof of IC for the agents is similar to Vickrey’s argument for single object auctions (Vickrey, 1961). Suppose a carrier j with reservation value s j submits a sealed bid s ˆ j and other agents submit their real valuations. If s j < s L , underbidding ( s ˆ j < s j ) will provide the carrier the same utility as if he bids s j ; overbidding ( s ˆ j > s j ) may induce him to lose the trade, and even if he wins the trade ( s j < s ˆ j < s L ) , he obtain the same utility if he bids truthfully. If s j ⩾ s L , underbidding ( s ˆ j < s j ) will cause negative utility for the carrier if he is involved in the final trade ( s ˆ j < s L ⩽ s j ) ; even if the carrier does not win the trade, he will get zero, the same as if he bids s j . Overbidding ( s L ⩽ s j < s ˆ j ) merely generates zero utility for the carrier, the same as if he bids truthfully. The shippers with indices i < K get part of their demands due to q i ′ ⩽ X i ′ . However, since every shipper’s volume ( q i ′ ) only depends on the mount of her demand and ranking, both of which are independent with her bid, no shipper can increase her volume by bidding untruthfully. Furthermore, for the same reason as stated for the carriers, every shipper will tell the truth if other agents do so. Thus, MTR mechanism is IC (weakly truth-telling) for all the agents. Since b ˆ K ⩾ s ˆ L , MTR mechanism always gives non-negative payoff for the auctioneer and hence it is weakly BB. The MTR mechanism is also IR because every agent obtains non-negative utility by engaging in the auction.
